speaker: Mr Hardgrave (Moreton) (6.05 P.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to be associated with theTuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 5475 dented. They have been hurt by the false starts and the promises of that Labor regime. What do Labor say these days: if only they had a fourteenth year, it would have been okay. I certainly do support the approach that the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) has offered. We do not need any more boom and bust in this country; we need no more kick in the guts economics as one lever is pulled here and something else is pulled there to just go on and produce more hurt and confusion. This government instead is working on the big structural changes, sustained and substantial economic growth and a return of a sense of security for Australians. We are talking about low inflation. We are talking about steady growth over the next decade. We are talking about repairing the financial situation that Labor left us. We are talking about reducing debt. We are talking about boosting investment. All of this equals job creation, and that is what it is all about. If throwing money at job creation would have solved the problems of unemployment, Labor would have fixed them. Instead, over 13 years they averaged 8.7 per cent unemployment in this country . Yet they stand here in their contributions to this debate and try and revisit the whole thing and suggest they have all the answers now. If only they had a fourteenth or fifteenth year, they keep saying. Let us face it, Mr Deputy Speaker, all Labor do is knock. All they want to do is knock, and prevent the government from getting on with its established program. If you look at the recent Yellow Pages business survey, it showed that 30 per cent of small business believes the economy a year from now will be better, and 13 per cent say it will be worse. For my money, I will go with the 30 per cent. In the survey, small business was also asked what its prime concerns were. Third on the list of prime concerns was cash flow, at 11 per cent. The second concern for small business was lack of sales at 21 per cent. According to that Yellow Pages small business survey, the number one prime concern of the small business sector, a concern for 28 per cent of small business people, was none; there was absolutely no concern for them. The number one concern of 28 per cent of small business operators was no concern at all. The Labor opposition in recent weeks has been touting the positive-negative indicators of that particular survey. Statistically, this outlines where the positives outweigh the negatives in the survey. This latest Yellow Pages index shows that negatives outweigh the positives to the tune of minus six per cent. That is a vast improvement on the last such survey under the previous government, where the result was minus 51 per cent. In other words, while small business would like to be happier-and I am sure most people on the government side understand all of this-the one thing that is for certain is that they are far more confident than when Labor was in power. We will keep working on that growing confidence. We will keep working on the job of restoring confidence to the small business sector and, as the policies and measures we have undertaken kick in, confidence will grow even stronger. Already we have seen evidence of the growth in confidence. The March quarter capital expenditure survey backs up the basis of the bill which is before us this evening: strong growth in business investment in 1996-97. Business is starting to gear up again. Total capital expenditure in the first three quarters of 1996-97 is 21 per cent higher than it was for the equivalent period a year ago. Business investment is very strong-at record levels-because of this government's lead. Interest rates are in fact at historic lows, and in addition the budget is turning from deficit to surplus. 5476 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 What is the Labor opposition's approach on all of this? They have basically opposed every point. The government's efforts to lock in monetary targets, low inflation, agreements between the Reserve Bank and the government: Labor just raved on and threatened to sue. The government's policy to take a $10.3 billion deficit and produce a $1.6 billion budget surplus was voted against on all measures by Labor. While this government stands for savings, low deficits, reduced debt and low interest rates, Labor is still the party of high deficits-who cares about that, they say-high debt, high interest rates, high taxes and no small business accommodation. No-one on the opposition side understands small business. There was evidence enough of that after 13 years of its dreadful government. While on this side we stand for small business, the return of confidence, investment and the creation of real jobs, in the Labor Party the contrast continues. Labor wants to slow down our programs of reform and thwart our efforts through the Senate. The Australian Democrats and the ALP should stand condemned for the hurt that their delays are causing. The great debate is starting-and we would like it to be a mature debate--on the question of reform of the taxation system. Everybody in this country, except the Labor Party, accepts that there is a need for reform. Already, it is showing it wants to play politics yet again. If Labor delays the reforms that may come out of the debate process, battlers in this country, people on average wages, are going to start paying the top rate of tax. Rather than grow up and participate in a mature debate on the taxation system, Labor would much rather see average weekly wage earners paying the top rate of tax. It would much rather see more job losses in the public sector, as well as the private, rather than face up to tax reform. After all, the evidence is there-elements of last year's budget were still being passed the day before this year's budget was introduced. A good example of the effect of that is the Mount Gravatt Training Centre in my electorate. Pat Milley and her team have been waiting for the new training regime to start. They have been putting time and effort in since this government came to power, planning for the future. That centre is committed to the training of people for new jobs, and yet the Labor-Democrat cabal and its delays in the Senate have caused lost staff, lost expertise, a decline in the esprit de corps, and lost morale. They will not pass those bills in the Senate. They have put them in a very long queue. What about the thousands of people in and around my electorate who could have been helped by the training that Pat and her team wanted to provide? Does Labor care? Obviously not, otherwise it would expedite matters in the other place. Compare this reckless approach to the devil-may-care, all risk, no responsibility approach of Crean and the $2 billion new work opportunities approach of the previous government. That $2 billion new work opportunities fiasco is part of the debt reduction program costs that we now face as a government. So desperate was the previous government to cover up unemployment before the last election, it threw money at it-$2 billion. One group which received funds in my electorate was the Brisbane South Community Group. Between 21 August and 7 November 1995, that group received $618,952 in three separate contracted amounts. It has received nothing since this government came to office. That was frustrating for me at the outset because I sought to represent their views and concerns, but now I understand why they have not received the money. It is because the earlier funds have not been acquitted. In other words, over $600,000 was thrown at this community group under Tuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5477 Labor-under its drunken spending spree on new work opportunities-and no money has so far been acquitted. Former employees of this particular organisation have raised matters with me, as have so many others in my local community who have lent moral support to Brisbane South Community Group--churches, service clubs, political representatives on all sides-and I now feel rather used and cheated by this organisation. Brisbane South Community Group failed to pay employees. It failed to pay the Australian Taxation Office PA YE collections. It failed to pay rent. It failed to pay Telstra bills. It failed to do a lot of things, and yet it was the recipient of money under the devil-may-care approach of the previous government. The Brisbane South Community Group has been kicked out of its Annerley office in my electorate. It has been kicked out of the Victoria Point office in the electorate of the honourable member for Fadden and Minister for Administrative Services( Mr Jull). It claims that the Mount Gravatt office is still operating-it is an office which we shared with the accounted for them. Past staff, community group members, service club members and local schools have all painted the same picture to me. Rosebud Hansen, a tireless worker in the Annerley area, and Kaye Bailey were two exworkers who took action, quite rightly, before the Industrial Relations Commission recently. They are seeking redress for their wage complaints. Last month the company chairman, Robin Whittaker, was ordered to pay $10,000 to those two women. If funds are not paid by the end of June, a warrant will be issued allowing police to seize property belonging to the company and to Mr Whittaker. The ATO is also after the Brisbane South Community Group for failure to pay $64,073 in group income tax. The company started to fail to pay wages in February 1996, just three months after the last dollop of Labor's NWO slush fund was received. The Queensland government has even chipped in with over $40,000 in funds last year for programs run by Rosebud Hansen, and yet she was not paid. I have been lobbied since the election by the group, especially by program coordinator, Aaron Lucas. I went in to bat for them because they presented themselves so well, had the backing of so many good, decent, committed citizens in my electorate, and had high aspirations. However, along with so many others, I know I have been used and misled. Where the funds have gone and why the hopes of hundreds of young unemployed have been dashed are questions which beg an answer. It is obvious to me that the Brisbane South Community Group was born out of an unreal environment prior to the last election. It was encouraged by a government which really was not interested in job creation, it was interested only in hiding the unemployed. So over $600,000 worth of taxpayers' funds have not been acquitted. Yet, down to their last breath, they are claiming the lack of acquittal of funds arises because of some obscure litigation involving their auditor. This Mr Aaron Lucas has also used my representations to Senator Vanstone seeking clarification of a lack of funds from the new government as an excuse to debtors. It also seems that he claimed constantly that more money was coming and that bills would be paid. Essentially, the imprimatur of the government's new programs was being used by this group. This government has not fallen for that, unlike the previous government. It has been frustrating to me that while my representations on behalf of so many other groups have been successful, this group was unsuccessful, but now we know. I must say that if only

theText: 5478 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 with the funds that it threw at new work opportunities prior to the last elections, this money would never have been wasted. Essentially, the whole episode disgusts me and so many others in my community. Local papers will be running this story tomorrow. I must say that when it is all said and done, in the context of this bill before us today, it is refreshing to see that we now have a government that has focused on real job creation, on long-term investment that is going to produce results, and is not prepared to just throw money at the problem and hope it fixes itself, as Labor did. There is no doubt that the Labor Party and the Democrats will stand in the way of so many more of this new government's efforts to do something genuine for the unemployed, and that amazes me. If this bill is not passed wholly in the Senate, then those two parties should stand condemned. the Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1997-98. For my electorate of Gilmore, this budget has been a good news budget as it acknowledges my three core commitments to the electorate: investment, infrastructure and jobs. The Treasurer's statements were well received as the people of Gilmore are fully aware of the pressing economic circumstances that make the need to balance the budget a government priority. It is something they understand in their own lives. They know that no-one can live beyond their means and that if you owe money, it has to be paid back. They understand that ultimately they will be the people who have to repay that debt. Therefore, it is certainly good news to see the government widen its ongoing commitment to Gilmore by providing solutions to the very real problems facing rural and regional Australia. However, a good budget alone, no matter how positive the initiatives, no matter how high the level of government financial commitment, is still not sufficient to address the real social problems faced by too many families in Gilmore. Although today I will speak about what Gilmore has gained, not for a moment have I lost sight of what is still to be achieved in an area in which unemployment and concerns for small business remain very high. After 13 years in which the difficulties faced by Gilmore were not recognised, I have always maintained that, given some assistance in providing infrastructure, then investments, jobs and self-reliance would follow. Whilst this budget makes no direct reference to our much needed major highway link, Main Road 92, the Shoalhaven Highway, work is continuing with the three tiers of government working together in preparing a feasibility study for making this major highway link a reality. There is no doubt that this access to the Hume Highway and Canberra is of vital importance to Gilmore's economic future. Our export markets are increasing and we need an alternate route through which to transport our goods. At the moment the beautiful, environmentally sensitive area of Kangaroo Valley is bearing the brunt of the traffic, and the trucks, and now double-B bogies, as there is simply no alternative to the Nowra-Canberra-Melbourne freight connection. Already there has been a commitment made by the Shoalhaven City Council in funding the initial studies that have proven the immense cost-benefit ratio to my electorate and adjoining regions and I congratulate the Shoalhaven City Council on showing the required leadership in dealing with such a pressing issue. There is no doubt that, with the commenced upgrading of HMAS Albatross, Main Road 92 will allow further gains to be made by easier, quicker access to defence links and embassies in Canberra. This will then become a road link of national significance.

speaker: Mrs Gash (Gilmore) (6.18 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased to be able to participate in this debate onTuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5479 The commencement of the eastern gas pipeline also displays confidence in my electorate of Gilmore with the major part of its construction following the proposed Main Road 92 route. This would clearly provide for the expansion of those areas, thus guaranteeing future investment in the area and much needed job creation. Whilst the Department of Defence has been, to a great extent, immune to the hardship experienced by other departments, a great deal of internal restructuring has taken place. Fortunately for the people of Gilmore, this has meant increased spending on our defence operations, and with it the decision to strengthen the operations of HMAS Albatross, a major naval base located in my electorate to the south of Nowra. A stage 1 budget of $35 million was allocated, providing an influx of capital into the community in the course of this financial year. That will mean more jobs for local residents and businesses. But, more importantly, the government has kept its word on its long-term commitment to the area by providing capital funding for major works at Albatross for many years to come. The upgrading at Albatross will benefit our community in many ways by the extension to and maintenance of defence personnel housing. In fact, a further 52 houses will be built and/or replaced. These will either be purchased in the local market or built by local operators at an estimated cost of $5 1/2 million. All this contributes to giving the local economy the short-term kick-start it so desperately needs and long-term assurances that any business in the area cannot ignore. I thank the minister and his staff for their efforts to bring about an outcome so beneficial to my community. I have never subscribed to the view that development must come at the expense of the environment, and neither has this government. To date, some $280,000 has been received for Coastcare projects. I am extremely hopeful that the government's $1 billion National Heritage Trust will directly benefit our environment, with our pristine icon of Jervis Bay, a myriad of waterways and an unsurpassed ecosystem. In fact, the recent announcement of this government's funding of $6.9 million for the Nowra university will see it in operation by the year 2000. We are also quietly confident that our heritage fund will assist in making the technology for Jervis Bay the foundation of ocean medicine development, food cultivation and fish farming. There are many stakeholders in our coastal environment. They include developers, federal, state and local government, Aboriginal communities, commercial and industrial users and those who earn their living from the coast, such as our fishermen at Ulladulla and surrounding villages. Given such strong and competitive interests and commitment, there is obviously a need to balance these at government and community level. Therefore, I cannot stress enough the importance of a National Heritage Trust for my electorate of Gilmore. I have spoken in the House before about the level of unemployment in Gilmore. It is no secret that the number of jobless is disproportionately high in our area. This concerns me greatly. However, the message I get in my meetings with both the jobless and small business operators is unchanged: let small business employ, let it expand and create opportunities for the jobless and, above all, help small business remove the industrial shackles imposed by years of Labor neglect. This government has also contributed half a million dollars towards a business incubator in my electorate of Gilmore-another example of small business and the unemployed being recognised by this government. I am simply amazed by Labor's refusal to support our small business by the further reform of unfair dismissal legislation. It is well 5480 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 known that the demands of current unfair dismissal legislation are the biggest deterrents for businesses employing fewer than 15 employees. The launching of our supermarket to Asia project in the next few months will be yet another incentive for businesses in my electorate. The project will have the clear objective of devising a more effective strategy for marketing the produce of local farmers and businesses. This will be of particular significance to us, as there is no doubt that there is a market for our products in Asia and the Middle East. The supermarket to Asia project will expand our strategy and bring our products to the attention of importers throughout the region. This will be another example of three tiers of government working together for the long-term prosperity of our community. Still on the topic of investment, as of 1 July what all businesses have asked for is the capital gains tax rollover of funds with the $5 million for reinvestment into other business or for retirement superannuation. In a perfect world there would be no need for DSS offices in my electorate of Gilmore; everyone would have jobs and no-one would be in need of government assistance. Unfortunately, a perfect world is still a fair way off. Therefore, with the support of DSS manager David Tagg and his enthusiastic staff, I am pleased to announce that Gilmore has received the go-ahead for the establishment of a new one-stop shop DSS. This project is worth over $1 million to our community and again shows this government's commitment to regional Australia. I have reminded my constituents that it was this government that increased the allowance for carers-of which we have many. On top of that, in Gilmore we have received another 40 aged care places for those who wish to remain at home, with appropriate care, as opposed to going into a nursing home. Another issue which has raised debate in my electorate is the recent Bringing them home report, which has given all Australians a chance to reflect on our history and the role it plays in defining our national identity. An unfortunate outcome of the report has been a hardening of two philosophical positions. Some endorse what has been referred to as the 'black armband' view of our history, focusing on the sins of our forefathers. In so doing, people make no reference to the important and commendable achievements made in 200 years of European civilisation in this country. There is another school of thought that would have us believe that this history is irrelevant to our everyday lives, that the injustices suffered by our indigenous population are in no way connected to the plight of Gilmore's Aboriginal communities today. Like so many of those that I have spoken to in my electorate, I see myself as somewhere in the middle of the spectrum. WhatI advocate is a type of compassionate pragmatism and a total and frank recognition of what has happened in Australia, but always with an eye on the best way forward. Last week, an Aboriginal elder came to speak to me about recent developments. She explained that for her, the stolen generation is an example of history affecting the present. It is a wound that will not heal for many Aboriginal Australians; a pain which cannot be erased and will be part of the identity of indigenous Australians for generations to come. This is something I accept completely. I have no qualms in personally saying, 'Sorry', as there is no need to see a personal apology as a recognition of personal responsibility. I was not involved with the tragic events and my personal apology is merely a recognition that Australian history has been kind to me while forcing enormous hardships onto fellow Australians. As politicians, Tuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5481 we should be capable of acknowledging the emotional depth of the issues we discuss and responding to such issues with compassion and sensitivity. It is also important that while condemning the practice of the removal of Aboriginal children, we do not overlook the fact that in some cases at least, meaningful and loving relationships were formed between the removed children and their adoptive families. I now look forward to being part of a government that looks to the future, to the creation of a brighter future for all Australian individuals, and for all of Australia's most needy communities. In conclusion, as I stated earlier, for Gilmore it was certainly a good news budget, one that will create even greater opportunities as we pursue the potential for federation funding and the National Heritage Trust. pleased to respond to the debate in respect of the Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1997-98 on behalf of the government and the Treasurer ( Mr Costello), in particular. I note that some 40 to 45 members of the government have contributed to this debate and supported the budget measures introduced by the Treasurer. What that debate has shown is that there is enormous support from both within this parliament-particularly all members of the government-but more particularly from outside the parliament, from the business sector and from the Australian electorate generally. The reason for that is that, in an economically responsible manner, the budget builds upon and it extends the progress that is being made by the Howard-Fischer budget some nine months ago. First and foremost, this budget is about a fair and equitable approach to the government's accounts. The consolidated measures of the government have turned around a $10.3 billion deficit that was left to us, of course, by Labor and turned it into a sizeable headline surplus in the 1997-98 budget of some $5 billion and, by 1998-99, there will be an underlying surplus of $1.6 billion. For the first time in almost a decade-in fact, for the first time this decadethe Minister for Finance did not have to follow the Treasurer on budget night and introduce a loan bill. The fact is that in this coming year the Commonwealth will repay over $5 billion of government debt. That will free future generations of Australians from the debt associated with servicing the debt that was threatening to drown this particular parliament, this particular government and this particular operation of government. So successful is the government's strategy of addressing the overall structure of the budget that it has been estimated that in the period since the government came into office until the year 2000-2001, the Commonwealth's net debt to GDP ratio will almost halve. This will ensure that Australians can face the new millennium in the knowledge that the country's future has been secured. The remarkable turnaround has occurred without having to increase taxes, be it income tax, company tax, wholesale sales tax, or for that matter, excise on petrol. Despite the difficulties faced in addressing the structural problems in the budget left to us by Labor, we have been able to introduce a number of initiatives in this budget. I will just add a couple of those initiatives. We have introduced, for the first time by an Australian government, a broadly based savings rebate; improvements in the superannuation arrangements and the tightening of rules governing access to superannuation prior to retirement; the provision of greater choice about where Australians can invest their superannuation contributions; the introduction of a deferred pension bonus plan for older Australians; a commitment to maintain the pension at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings; and

theText: Minister for Finance) (6.27 p.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker, I am5482 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 the increase in the ordinary domiciliary nursing care benefit to align it with the child disability allowance. Other features include: additional funding of $54 million under the Commonwealth-state disability agreement; improvements to entry level training incentive payments designed to encourage employers to take on apprentices and trainees; introduction of the work for the dole scheme; building on the government's commitment to reduce compliance costs for small business by streamlining the withholding tax arrangements; and the doubling of the deduction under the income test for second and subsequent children to allow more families access to Austudy. Yet more features include: an additional $76 million to increase our quarantine capacity and improve our quarantine service; the provision of $1.25 billion for expenditure by the Natural Heritage Trust over the next six years; and the creation of the Federation Fund to finance major projects of national significance to mark the centenary of Federation and to contribute to many of Australia's infrastructure needs for the coming century. In summary, the budget builds upon the strategy begun in last year's budget to tum around Australia's financial position and to provide the framework to accelerate the pace of sustainable economic growth, the creation of real job opportunities and the maintenance of a regime of lower interest rates. The main problem the Labor Party has with the budget strategy is its reliance on failed economic dogma. It very much reflects the coalition's wasted years in opposition and its inability to fashion a ·':t'orm program outside the shortcomings of orthodox economic theory. In rclation to Appropriation Bill (No.2) 1997-98 and its budget stratcgy, it is very clear that a measure of the government's failure comes from its own determination to hold out tax reform as something of a distraction to the way in which the budget has been received around the country. speaker: Mr Latham (Werriwa) (8.00 P.m.)
theText: I am here this evening representing the shadowTuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5483 They will remember the determination of the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) to move public attention onto the question of a GST instead of the government going through the normal process of moving around the country to provide confidence in the economic strategy. A division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 8.02 p.m. to 8.15 p.m. demolishing the government's budget strategy and exposing its many flaws. Now, thankfully, I have been advised that the main purpose of this debate is to address capital outlays in the budget, so having dispensed with the general strategy I can move to the more specific. There is an item out of my electorate that is a capital works of great waste. The fact that the government in this budget and, I believe, in earlier budgets has been allocating funds for the construction of a hospital, an important capital facility, at the Holsworthy army base is an appropriation that needs to be questioned, more so with the Minister for Finance( Mr Fahey) present in the Main Committee chamber. How wasteful it is for a government to be outlaying some $20 million on the construction of a hospital at Holsworthy when the government also has these grievous plans for the construction of Sydney's second international airport on the same site. When this proposition was first raised, I had a concern that the hospital might in fact be adept forward planning; the idea that, with all that unexploded ordnance around at Holsworthy, the first plane that would land at such an airport may well require a modem, state of the art hospital nearby for the looming catastrophe. If the government is engaging in that sort of forward planning, I would ask them to desist. There is a better way to handle this matter, of course, and that is not to engage in the folly of Holsworthy, and to allow the $20 million to be well spent. I am sure the military hospital relocated out of my electorate, at Ingleburn, to the seat of Hughes, at the Holsworthy base, is a needed facility. There is no doubt about that. But it has to be a facility that is used for military purposes, not to literally mop up the tragedy of bad planning and bad decision making in relation to the site of Sydney's second international airport. I know, in making those comments, that that is a proposition that the Minister for Finance would support for two reasons. One is: why waste $20 million on the construction of a hospital when the government also has a plan for an airport? But I also know-and this is the second reason-that he is busting out of his skin to actually say something about Holsworthy and engage himself in the public debate. The only thing that is stopping him is said to be the release of the EIS. Why someone needs an EIS to tell them that an international airport with two 4,000-metre runways directed at large residential areas is a problem, I am yet to work out. But if the Minister for Finance can just use a bit of logic in this matter, and understand that his constituents are screaming for representation and screaming for him to say something about Holsworthy, maybe this issue of the capital outlay for the hospital is his entree to that particular debate. So, as Minister for Finance and member for Macarthur, at long last he can find a legitimate reason to enter the Holsworthy debate, to actually represent the people in his electorate who are so concerned, and to do it in a fiscally responsible fashion. That is, to say that the capital outlay for the hospital would be wasted if the airport goes ahead and the hospital and other major facilities need to be demolished, and that this is a poor allocation of Commonwealth funding.

speaker: Mr Jenkins (Scullin) (8.24 P.m.)
theText: In speaking to this set of expenditures, I mention that5486 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 As I indicated in my second reading speech, on the evidence of the Secretary of the Treasury to the Senate estimates committee, the Treasury has indicated-unlike the Treasurer-that perhaps there is some doubt about the potential effectiveness of the scheme as proposed, in that it may not have the required outcome on national savings. I wish to take this opportunity to talk about the saving scheme in relation to my electorate because I believe that it is a sick joke that will do nothing for the majority of my constituents. The latest available figures released by the Australian Taxation Office show that half of the taxpayers in Lalor, Thomastown and Epping-suburbs within my electorate-did not earn any interest from savings at all. These people will get no savings rebate whatsoever. Those people who had savings which earned interest earned an average of $492. This translates into an average annual rebate of $74 per year-about $1.40 a week, or less than 20c a day. ThisI believe to be a sad joke. Perhaps my constituents will be able to put this pathetic amount towards their child-care costs, which will increase because of cuts in this area. Perhaps they will be able to put it towards the increased costs of their medication because of the changes to the PBS. Perhaps they can put the 20c towards the nursing home entry charges for their parents that this government seeks to introduce. Perhaps it can be used towards their fee for employment services, which the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, seeks to introduce. Half of these people will receive an average rebate of 20c; the other half will receive nothing. This savings initiative is nothing but a shameful hoax. It is all the more contemptible because it comes at the expense of superannuation contributions which would have assisted these people in retirement and would have achieved a great deal towards boosting national savings. Those in their mid-30s on average weekly earnings who are lucky enough to get the 20c a day must be aware that it comes at the expense of $110,000 from their retirement income packages-that is, $110,000 less towards national savings. In putting together the statistics for the suburbs in my electorate, I was particularly disappointed to find that the Australian Taxation Office no longer gives the type of detail by postcode that it used to. I believe that, in the interests of meaningful analysis, the ATO should attempt to present the statistics in such a way that they are easily able to be compared. It is also interesting that, since the bringing down of the budget by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) has gone into his kitbag of emergency notions to try to deflect from other issues and grabbed at tax reform, but tax reform in the minds of this government is a code for the introduction of a GST. At the time when a GST was previously proposed, it was contended by the proposers that a consumption tax in some way leads to an increase in national savings on the basis that, because it is a tax on consumption, people will be less likely to consume and, therefore, spend money and thus retain savings. The people in the suburbs that I mentioned earlier have very little non-discretionary expenditure. They will not be able not to decide to buy the things that they need for day-to-day living and, therefore, there will be no effect on national savings because of those people's expenditure and spending patterns. I believe that as the debate continues on the goods and services tax-because that appears to be the major plank that the government proposes to raise as part of its tax reform package-we will need to look at the experiences in other countries that have shown that these types of GSTs have not had the proposed effect on savings. Tuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5487 The debate that we are going to see about a GST is not a substitute for the government looking at policies in the area of employment. The GST and the types of tax reforms that the government is going to propose in the lead-up to the next election do nothing for the creation of jobs or to give people a greater sense of job security. Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1997-98 to the foreign aid allocation for 1997-98 and, in particular, to the allocation for Africa. It is deplorable that for the second year under the Liberal government the ODA vote has been reduced in nominal terms and that it has been cut in real terms by 12.6 per cent over the past two years. As a percentage of GDP, it has fallen from 0.31 per cent to 0.27 per cent in that time-the lowest level for several decades. But even more deplorable is the cut in aid to Africa, aid which has been reduced in nominal terms from $108.7 million in 1995-96 to $87.7 million in 1997-98-a cut of $21 million or 19.3 per cent. In real terms, this amounts to a cut of 22.7 per cent. That is a reduction of almost one-quarter in just two years-almost double the real cut in total aid. Why was Africa singled out for especially severe treatment? The government, through its minister or in its budget papers, gives no explanation except to try to excuse the cut by pointing to the IDA contribution to the World Bank and saying that, as 40 per cent of the International Development Association funds are allocated to Africa, 40 per cent of our IDA contribution for 1997-98 of $121.5 million will be spent in Africa, resulting in a total Australian contribution to Africa of $140 million. However, this excuse ignores the fact that this point is true every year and that the allocation for IDA this year is actually $6 million less than for the previous year. The $140 million figure is also a rounding-up of an actual figure of $136.3 million. The reality is that there is no excuse for cutting funds to Africa, especially not to a greater degree than the cut to aid overall. This is especially so if, as the minister claims in his foreword to the budget paper on page xi under the heading of Australia's overseas aid program 1997-98, the principal objectives of Australia's aid program should be to ensure the reduction of poverty and the promotion of economic development as a permanent means of overcoming such poverty. If those are the principal objectives of the government's aid, how can it possibly justify slashing funds by one-quarter for the poorest continent in the world, the continent experiencing the greatest difficulty in achieving economic development? Just look at the facts: 33 of the 48 least developed countries in the world are in Africa. Most of these countries have a GDP per capita of less than $US2 per day. Indeed, World Bank figures show that, in 1993, there were 219 million people in sub-Saharan Africa-40 per cent of the region's population-living on less than $USI per day, and that that number had increased by 40 million in the six years up to 1993. In regard to poverty, Africa, especially sub-Saharan Africa, is clearly well qualified for our aid. With regard to economic development, Africa's economic performance has been very poor until the past year or so. Over the 15 years from 1980-94, real GDP per capita for Africa declined by 15 per cent. Many African countries now have a level of real income per head less than in 1970. theText: I want to address my remarks in the debate on5488 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 overall growth rate of five per cent in 1996 and a similar outcome expected this year-these rates of growth are nowhere near high enough to make a marked im;Jact on widespread poverty. Clearly, that is not going to happen. World Bank forecasts are for growth in sub-Saharan Africa to be 3Y2 to four per cent in the near future. A major debilitating impediment to growth in many African countries is their extremely high levels of foreign debt and official debt. Of the 41 most indebted poor countries in the world in 1994, 27 had a foreign debt to GDP ratio of over 100 per cent, and 21 of those countries were African. Furthermore, 13 of those 27 countries-12 of them African-had scheduled interest payments on government borrowings of over 100 per cent of government revenue. Obviously, they cannot allocate anywhere near 100 per cent of revenue to their debt servicing, so their debt mounts inexorably and their financial predicament becomes even more excruciating. Of course, such countries obtain virtually no benefit from rapidly expanding private capital flows to developing countries, flows which all go to a handful of countries. Sub-Saharan Africa got 3.6 per cent of foreign direct investment to developing countries in 1994. Accordingly, the foreign aid allocation for Africa is highly unrepresentative of the need for economic development in that region. I thought that at some time the cuts last year, savage as they were, would have only been a temporary measure and we would have started to redress the balance. These population programs are important, especially to our near neighbours in the Pacific. We are sending all the wrong messages. I said that last year, and nothing has changed my mind. We are sending the wrong messages to those Pacific countries. We are indicating to them that Australia does not care, that Australia has no concern for them. The one issue that I and everyone I speak to cannot understand is the cut to Radio Australia. Why do it? Minister, you more than most of us would know the important role that Radio Australia plays throughout Asia. It is not expensive-a couple of posts at a mission would pay for it. However, once we cut that service it will never recover. Do not think that by us cutting our radio service that there is not going to be a service there. The Brits are coming in, as are the French and the Chinese. Many nations are trying to come in there. At the very time when other countries are coming in and when Australia is making much of our relationship with Asia, we are cutting the cheapest and most effective way of getting across our message to Asia about what Australia is and what it stands for. We are doing that by cutting funds to Radio Australia. (Time expired) I want to indicate that I believe there is another reason why we should be maintaining, if not increasing, funds to Africa. Despite the concern this disease has created in developed countries, it is the developing countries, which account for 90 per cent of HIV/AIDS sufferers, which have the real problem. Nowhere is this more true than in sub-Saharan Africa where 13 million people have HIVI AIDS-that is, about 60 per cent of the world total. The extent of this epidemic in a number of sub-Saharan countries is absolutely devastating. This did not include full-blown AIDS sufferers. One in three of the population aged between 15 and 50 was HIV positive. In Botswania, population 1.4 million, an estimated 180,000 people, or 13 per cent of the population, were HIV positive. speaker: Mr Willis (Gellibrand) (8.40 P.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, further to my earlier remarks,5490 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 pOSltlve---over 10 per cent of the population. By way of comparison, Australia, with a population of 18 million, has about 11,000 people currently living with HIVI AIDS-that is, 0.06 per cent of the population. The impact of this pandemic on the sub-Sahara is already severe and will become more so as the vast numbers of HIV infected people become AIDS sufferers. Apart from the great increase in human suffering and loss of life, there are extremely serious social, economic and even potentially political consequences from this holocaust. Family life is being devastated by the death of parents, with many children ending up in crowded orphanages or becoming homeless street kids in the cities. Families are forced into debt and poverty through the extra health cost they have to bear and the loss of productive family members. Education levels are being reduced through the inability of stricken families to afford school fees or because children are needed to earn a living or to care for the sick, and also because of the deaths of many teachers. The health system of these countries is being overwhelmed. In Zimbabwe, in many hospitals over half of the beds are taken up with sufferers from HIVrelated illnesses. The economies of these countries are also being severely affected. Large additional costs are imposed on the economy through the need to fund prevention programs, as well as greatly increased health costs to care for those infected. This puts great pressure on already strained. if not overwhelmed, budgets and crowds out any other necessary expenditures for social and economic development. Furthermore, with the disease concentrated on the most productive age group, the widespread loss of skilled personnel is reducing both the quantity and quality of labour. This is especially the case for white-collar professionals, which group has the highest incidence of infection. Accordingly, these countries are losing many of their most skilled managerial and professional people in business, the public service, teaching and academia. Even parliaments are severely affected. For instance, in Zambia, which has a parliament of 155 seats, there have been 22 by-elections in the last two years due to deaths, of which 20 are thought to be AIDS related. Thus, institutional infrastructures and the quality of government are at risk of being undermined by the loss of such personnel. So too are the enterprises of these nations which face continual loss of their key personnel and management, loss of productivity through employees being ill on the job or absent because of their illness or the illness of other family members. The impact on some industries will be absolutely staggering. In Zambia, a study of the copper industry several years ago showed 60 per cent of the labour force in the industry were HIV positive-this in an industry which accounts for 90 per cent of Zambian exports and 25 per cent of its GDP. Exports from these countries will also be adversely affected by the impact of HIV/AIDS on agriculture and the likely diversion of tourism to less risky destinations. However, the statistic that perhaps best sums up the horrific nature of what is happening in these countries is UNDP's estimate that, without AIDS, African life expectancy would have been 62 years by the year 2000, but with AIDS it is expected to be only 47 years. How, one may ask, in the face of such a total calamity, can we in all conscience slash our aid to these countries? But that is what we have done. theText: Minister for Trade) (8.45 p.m.)Mr Deputy Speaker, thisTuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5491 the contribution he made to this estimates hearing, and also the sincerity of the views of the member for Throsby e Mr Hollis). In response to those views let me say that it is never easy, given the challenges of government, to work through an exact allocation of priorities within each portfolio and between portfolios. I am sure the memher for Gellibrand can well recall during his previous ministerial positions when in government just how difficult that process can be. You do have to make judgments on priorities. You do have to arrive at the right conclusions with regard to program allocations. This year Australia's aid budget under the provisions of this budget will be $1.430 billion. In the tight budgetary circumstances, as we build towards a surplus in next year's budget, this represents a decrease of only one per cent on the estimated 1996-97 outlays. It is a large amount of money; it is $1.430 billion. Yes, it has been shaved over the last two years and had we not been left with the huge Beazley $8 billion plus black hole, we would not have had to embark on this path. We are very conscious of the need to proceed with care. I take particular note of the comments of the member for Gellibrand with regard to the plague proportions and crisis proportions of AIDS and HIV. They are indeed very startling figures which he presented to the committee here tonight. The AusAid budget is a large budget, one carefully allocated and with a particular focus on countries in south Asia and other parts of Asia which are closer to home. That does not ignore completely the circumstances of Africa. As the member for Gellibrand has acknowledged, there is a continuing allocation, but it is one which he would like to see increased. I can only say that the government has, in the circumstances, done as much as it can do. Of course, we will continue to provide, through multilateral arrangements, additional aid with regard to HIV-AIDS worldwide. Turning to the comments of the member for Throsby, the closure of the Copenhagen and Nauru missions were difficult decisions, to be frank, and were ones which I know were carefully weighed by my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Alexander Downer, and myself and others before reaching that conclusion. In respect of Copenhagen I would point out that there are posts elsewhere in Europe in Athens, Belgrade, Berlin, Bonn, Brussels, Budapest, Dublin, Holy See, London, Madrid, Malta, Moscow, Nicosia, Paris, Rome, Stockholm, The Hague, Vienna and Warsaw. Locating posts involves getting the right balance between various parts of the world and within various regions of the world. It was not a decision taken lightly. Governments, from time to time, close posts, and governments, from time to time, open posts. For example, we have picked up on your decision of a couple of years back to reopen Beirut in Lebanon and retain that post. It is an important post in the Middle East. I note his comments with regard to Radio Australia that an additional $4 million was supplied from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to recover in part the reductions in budget allocation to Radio Australia. Radio Australia does have an important role to play. The real enemies of Radio Australia, I have since discovered, rested in the senior echelons of the ABC. If it were not for elements within the ABC and their agenda against Radio Australia, we would not have been presented with the shutdown circumstance we were confronted with. However, we have dealt with that, turned it around, and we have provided now for a continuing operation of Radio Australia, albeit on a reduced scale. 5492 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the estimate to the committee. I thank the member for Gellibrand and the member for Throsby for their deeply held views which they presented to the committee tonight. I also say to members of the committee, especially as they examine the trade side of things, to study the trade outcomes and objectives statement which I tabled at the start of this year. It gives a very good overview of our trading circumstance and it has a statistical backup. accept that the budgetary position excuses the cut in aid. The budget deficit that was left by the former government was one of the lowest budget deficits in the Western developed world, as was the level of government debt; and neither of those circumstances in any way justify cutting aid to people in tremendous need. As I have a bit more time now, I want to refer to a particular cut that was made in the budget in relation to a program which was advertised to non-government organisations last August. It was called the ANGOP, which I think is the African and non-government organisations program, and it has now been axed. But in February 1997, AusAID wrote to the Australian NGOs requesting project ideas by mid-April for a program that it had announced after last year's budget. They received 48 proposals. All the NGOs acted in good faith and put a great deal of effort and planning into the proposals. This work was matched by others in Africa, where communities and their leaders had also done a lot of work discussing and planning the types of projects which would respond to the needs of local communities. AusAID was due to announce the successful projects in the week after the budget was brought down. However, the NGO representatives were told, as part of a briefing on the night of the budget, that the program had been cancelled as a result of budget cuts. So a program was announced at the time of the last budget. Everyone worked like hell on it from August last year to May this year, and on the night of the budget they were told that all that was a waste, it was gone. This was not only work by people in the NGOs here in Australia, with their scarce resources allocated to working up good projects, but also work by people in Africa who had been very much involved in trying to work up those projects so that they were good, decent projects. World Vision has said that six of their projects have been axed as a result of the wiping of the scheme. They were: in Ethiopia, a project to improve the health of 41 ,000 people through clean water and improved sanitation; in Malawi, a project to provide HIV/AIDS education and home based care support to 62,000 people; in Malawi, a project to improve seed supply and to increase farm yields and food security for 30,000 people; in Uganda, a project to help 10,000 people affected by HIV/AIDS; in Mozambique, a project to improve the health of 20,000 people by improving water supply and sanitation facilities; and, in Mozambique, another project to improve the health of 37,000 people through improved water supply and sanitation facilities. That was just one NGO with six proposals. There were 48 altogether. The wiping of this program, announced in the last budget and knocked off on budget night this year, wipes out a whole raft of very decent projects which have been worked on assiduously by the NGOs. It has been a total waste of their time and effort in producing these projects and a total waste of the time and effort of a lot of people in Africa who have got better things to do in trying to make something of their lives than muck around with aid projects that do not come to anything. I think that has been a quite deplorable development.

That is very important in Africa. There is no point in us just saying that we have got to hand money over to them to waste because they do not have good governing and administrative procedures. We want to make sure there are good administration and good governance principles applying in the various nations of that continent, and there are recommendations in that report for that to happen. In the case of Zimbabwe, for instance, a number of people have come to this country from the parliament and there have been quite beneficial impacts from what was called the small activities scheme and the good governance program that was run under that. But, as a result of this budget, that scheme was knocked on the head. So there will be no more in the way of us helping to improve good governance in Africa through that program. That is just deplorable. It is tremendously wasteful. This is an area which everyone agrees is fundamental. We say to the Africans, 'You've got to lift your own game. theText: My question goes to trade and the emergence of5494 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 opportunities presented on the Internet. The government has outsourced the vetting process to a private sector company--coincidentally, a company which also engages in the marketing of encryption software. It eventuates that the company that also markets encryption software has said that it will take a great deal of time to assess this particular company's software and that will cost the very small business in Australia some $250,000. This is a small business that is trying to pitch a product at under $250 per unit per twin-site licence. So, in that environment, you have a small business that really has to do better than a company like BHP to make itself worthwhile. We have to get the balance right. I acknowledge that this has to be a whole-of-government approach to a fairly important question, but I also note that on page 52 of the portfolio budget statement of the department it says: Directions and outcomes of key international environment negotiations which safeguard or advance Australian economic, environmental and other interests ... When we talk about 'other interests' in this debate, we should not just talk about trade and industry interests alone; we should balance them against not only the world's environmental interests, but also Australia's environmental interests because, as I have said before, the environmental problems that the world has know no geopolitical boundaries. We have to keep that in consideration. The other thing I wish to touch upon briefly-and I know that the Acting Prime Minister, in his capacity as the Minister for Trade, has made his views pretty clear on this-is social clauses in trade agreements, whether they be multilateral agreements or bilateral agreements. Australia's role is to show leadership on these questions. It is in Australia's interests to develop some of these questions through trade agreements. One social matter that I have raised from time to time in this place is the question of child labour. This is a difficult problem for a number of countries within which child labour is practised. It is a very important problem for the economies of families and the like, but this is something on which Australia, in the best interests of Australia as a nation, needs to show leadership.

theText: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy) (9.14 p.m.)-I5498 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 responsibility to be compassionate to faun families who cannot meet their needs. On the other hand, we do not want to continue to create an environment in which much of the spirit of resilience, independence and innovation that has made the rural sector in this country so great is undermined. Finding the right balance is not easy. Let me say at the outset that one of the other major reports that we arc drawing on makes it plain that, despite some of the anecdotal evidence to the contrary, there is currently prevailing no failure of availability of farm finance to the rural sector. Businesses that have a future are able to draw on borrowings or on debt equity, if that is the way they choose to finance themselves-and, indeed, having been very closely involved with this portfolio for a long time, I must say that that has been my experience. It is a welcome change. It is unquestionably different from the situation which prevailed during the times of extraordinarily high interest rates that we saw under the previous regime. I make the point, too, that of far more value than interest rate subsidies-which, of course, we announced in the budget that we would no longer continue with-is a regime under which interest rates fall for everyone. As a general rule of thumb, only around six per cent of farmers at any given time were receiving interest rate subsidies or business support under normal RAS. It was always difficult to target and it was always hard to make it fair. There were always people who, by the criteria, should probably have been getting assistance but were not, and there were those who were getting assistance but who did not need or deserve that assistance. It is far better to get interest rates down for everyone, to develop a level playing field in which all can have the opportunity to maximise their performance. In that regard I want to say that, firstly, the government's fiscal consolidation objectives are plainly reaping benefits for farmers, but perhaps they were grossly underestimated. Some people talk a great deal about the $40 million-odd that went. into interest rate subsidies. The interest rates cuts that we have seen since this government came to power just 15 months ago are worth some $350 million to $400 million to the whole of the farm sector. Those cuts are extraordinarily valuable: they are the key to stabilising debt and the key to recovery. I note with a great deal of pleasure that farm debt in some sectors is now being wound back. Unfortunately, that is not true of the troubled beef sector and, at this stage, it is still not the case in the recovering wool industry. But many other sectors, including grain, appear to be not only starting to reinvest but also winding back debt levels, albeit not at a high rate; nonetheless, that is a very welcome development. The integrated rural policy package will deal with a wide range of issues, including a more streamlined, equitable and less ad hoc approach to farm welfare. It will also deal more effectively with the business needs of farmers: training, skills, benchmarking, marketing skills and more effective savings mechanisms such as IEDs, farm management bonds and those sorts of things. Finally, let me say that the supermarket to Asia program is an important one. If only it were as simple as being a matter of infrastructure; but it is not. It is about constantly upgrading Australia's approach to food safety, quality, packaging and marketing, if we are to achieve our objective of being a premier supplier of quality foodstuffs to our increasingly able-to-pay Asian neighbours. councillor gave an example of farmers who were trying to access small business loans at 7.9 per cent being turned away by the major banks and told that in fact they were not a small

They relate in particular to the relative funding and role of the Office of the Employment Advocate compared to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and what it reflects in terms of the priority of the government in comparing the significance of Australian workplace agreements to awards and other agreements which go through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. We have in this budget increased resources for the Office of the Employment Advocate and reduced resources for the Industrial Relations Commission. On the face of it there is a budget notation which indicates increased resources for the Industrial Relations Commission to discharge the extra functions that it has achieved as a result of the amalgamation with Victoria. However, as the Senate estimates committee process made clear when questioning the Registrar of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, when, if I can put it in the vernacular, the ons and offs are taken into account, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is substantially worse off. The registrar says the net result is about a $300,000 reduction in the running costs appropriation. Given the increased responsibilities of the commission as it relates to the handover in Victoria, that is a cause of concern to me. There was an unwelcome hiatus in the provision of resources to support workers and small business people seeking assistance from what was traditionally done by the Victorian government through Wageline, but I welcome the fact that there is now funding for that. That is, I assume, to be covered by this increased funding, but the cuts that flow with that to the resources of the Industrial Relations Commission make it less able to discharge that obligation. But I make that comment only as a backdrop. My particular concern is the role of the Office of the Employment Advocate. Of course, everybody knows, I assume, or at least those involved in this debate know, that the opposition's position is essentially that it is an office that should not exist. Half of its function should be performed by the Industrial Relations Commission and could be better done there and some should be done by the department. But that is irrelevant to this discussion. My concern is about the way that it is functioning and about the evidence that is emerging about the Australian workplace agreements for which it is responsible. The evidence before the estimates committee indicates an organisation operating in a bizarre fashion. I think the Employment Advocate thinks he is actually the Director-General of ASIO rather than the head of the Office of the Employment Advocate. He has undercover people running around, but only pursuing matters to do with freedom of association. There is no evidence at all of any spot-check or any activity about any employees concerned about any Australian workplace agreement. There is no argument about that.

With regard to his attack on me about the Employment Advocate, I made it clear this evening that, while I disagree with his view about the making available of Australian workplace agreements, that is a matter on which there is a possibility that there will be some contention. I accept that he has taken legal advice. I think he is wrong, but I accept that there could be some controversy about that. The question of whether guidelines for decision making should be available to the parliament is a well established matter going back four years. The possibility that they should not be made available seems to me, on the face of it, to be extraordinary. If there is some special circumstance in this matter, I will be fascinated to see what it is. The point that leads me to rise for a second time is actually the substance of the Australian workplace agreements that are emerging from the shadow of secrecy with which the government tries to drape it. The Employment Advocate-and in this instance I will say to his credit-has before the Senate estimates committee made it absolutely clear that the so called rock solid guarantee that no-one's take-home pay would be cut is and always was meaningless and is not reflected in this legislation in any way. What he said quite explicitly and accurately is that you cannot get less than the award which covers your area. I actually think that in the way he is interpreting the act that is not going to be the case, but that is not my point. There will be some evidence about that subsequently and we will deal with that. But where people have been operating for years and years on the basis of agreements that operate over and above an award the guarantee that they will not lose their take home pay means nothing, because the no disadvantage test operates against the award, which may be hundreds of dollars less than the prior take-home pay of the employees in question. After hearing the Prime Minister e Mr Howard) say they had a rock solid guarantee that no-one could cut their take-home pay, I am sure they would be surprised to find that this is what it means. Proposed expenditure agreed to. Department of Industry, Science and Tourism Proposed expenditure $1,699,412,000. I take the opportunity to make a few observations about the recent announcement made by BHP to cease primary steel production in Newcastle in September 1999. BHP established the steelworks in Newcastle in 1915. Since that time Newcastle has become very clearly and very firmly established as a steel producing centre, and the character of Newcastle since that time has always been identified in relation to steel production. I think this particular issue illustrates better than most other developments the general attitude of this government to issues of this kind. Steel making is a core activity in Newcastle and is recognised to be so. Despite the fact that BHP proposes to cease primary steel production in September 1999, the response of the government, first of all from the office of the Prime Minister( Mr Howard), was that the Prime Minister would hear any submissions in connection with that issue but he would not intervene. We did not expect the Prime Minister to go to Newcastle and demand that BHP steel production continue. We did not expect that to be the form of intervention. But we did expect the Prime Minister to act as a Prime Minister. The response of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism( Mr Moore) was that we have to accept the realities of the world market. The world market is such that the demand for steel is expanding. BHP, as a major Australian corporation, could have taken advantage of that. Despite the fact that 2,500 people will lose their jobs and 2,500 families will be disadvantaged directly, and in excess of 6,000 individuals and families at least will be disadvantaged indirectly, Mr Moore said, nevertheless, that it was a good day for BHP shares. I did not hear that said, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I have heard it reported; and I have not heard it denied. I am disappointed and disgusted if that was said. It was a good day for BHP shares and for BHP shareholders, and that just shows how crazy this whole position is. Within hours, the value of BHP share.> increased by $1 billion as a result of the announcement that it would cease steel making in Newcastle. In 1983, the Labor government inherited an industrial graveyard in Australia. Industry was inefficient and uncompetitive. The proportion of manufactured goods which we exported was relatively small. During the 13 years that Labor was in government that situation was turned around completely. That was largely as a result of the very dramatic restructuring which took place in the framework of industry in Australia to make it possible for Australian industry to become competitive and to export to a greater extent than it had before.

I will take an opportunity shortly to add further to these remarks. (Time expired) the future of the CSIRO research facility at Narayen near Mundubbera. Mundubbera is in my electorate, but Narayen is actually just across the border in the electorate of Hinkler. This has been a long standing research station on a very large property watered by a fine river system, and it is certainly an excellent property. It has a fine group of buildings, now mostly several decades old, an excellent airstrip and so it is well serviced as a property of quality, and a property which has the capacity to offer a facility for research in a wide variety of areas. It has traditionally been working in pasture research. Its future has come into question because the Beef Research Committee and, indeed, the beef industry as a whole are suggesting that there are other higher priorities now for industry research than pastures. Many people in the industry disagree with that assessment and believe that it is still very important to the grazing industry for beef producers to have available to them a research facility that can do work on developing the best possible pastures and appropriate management of such pastures. The facility has also played a major role in the development of the Belmont Red breed of cattle and has been involved in quite a deal of other work. Because the native pastures have been significantly improved as part of the pasture research, even though it is a large property, it has been necessary over recent times to lease some surrounding land to undertake some of their work. But the CSIRO have given no indication at this stage as to what the future of that research facility will be and the staff are naturally anxious about their future. The facility has been steadily wound down over recent years and the staff are also disappointed that the CSIRO has not given them an opportunity to undertake research in other areas. On a number of occasions they have put together proposals to undertake particular activities and these have not been taken up by CSIRO management. So it is not just a matter of the funding coming from industry sources; it is also a question as to whether there is any longer a commitment from the CSIRO to make effective use of this facility. Even if it is decided that, for one reason or another, there is no longer a future role for pasture research, then the property would have potential for quite a deal of other activities. theText: I wish to address budget paper No.4, for5508 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 The committee was able to establish that franchising contracts typically impose very heavy obligations on franchisees, while leaving franchisors' duties relatively undefined. It also points out that the obligations of the franchisor are vital to the franchising relationship and that these contracts, and the fact that franchisees have sunk costs into the venture, necessarily involve the danger of opportunistic abuse. The report states: The incentive that causes a business with sunk costs to stay in operation despite losses makes franchisees vulnerable to franchisor behaviour known as 'opportunism'. Because the franchisee will continue to operate even if it is not recovering its sunk investments, the franchisor can make decisions that induce such losses without the franchisee going out of business. When these decisions benefit the franchisor at the expense of the franchisee, the franchisor opportunistically extracts a portion of the franchisee's sunk costs. Similarly, the Business Law Committee of the Law Institute of Victoria provided examples of abuses in this area. They include rolling audits of the franchisee to gather evidence of the franchisee's non compliance, and in site specific franchises taking advantage of the franchisee's development of its economic area to force the franchisee to pay goodwill again for its business by threatening to open new stores nearby. All of these things added up to the committee making a recommendation that the Commonwealth should enact specific franchising legislation, providing for compulsory registration of franchisors and compliance with codes of practice. This is something that the House urgently needs to consider. We need change. If we look at the bankruptcy figures for recent months, we will find that bankruptcy has risen in excess of 20 per cent. theText: It is almost inconceivable that AustraliaTuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5509 can we do? What are your intentions?' That is not what is happening at the present time. The whole thing is an absolute disgrace! Labor had a steel plan when we came into government in 1983, and it was put into operation. At the time, there were 9,000 employees in steel production in Newcastle. As a result of our steel plan there was a major increase in productivity, which was encouraged and supported admirably by the unions and the work force. From 9,000 people directly involved in steel production in Newcastle the figure has been gradually reduced to what it is at the present time, to about 3,000. Those changes were gradual and were absorbed. There was an output of about 160 tonnes of steel per employee in Newcastle in 1983. They were told that it had to be 500 tonnes per employee, otherwise steel production could be under threat. They passed through the 500 tonnes target and reached 650 tonnes per employee; it is now about 700 tonnes per employee, and they have been told that if steel production is to continue in Australia it needs to be 1,000 tonnes per employee. We know exactly what the implications of all of this are. I said it before: government is about taking positive action and taking the initiative. It is also about responding to individual, family and community concerns. Just a week ago we had one of a number of gatherings in Newcastle to which the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism( Mr Moore) were both invited. They sent the member for La Trobe( Mr Charles). I say nothing against the member for La Trobe. He was courageous, and he was treated with every courtesy. But at that meeting we had present the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley), the shadow minister for industry, the member for Hotham( Mr Crean), the President of the ACTU, two bishops, four federal Labor members, six state Labor members, the Lord Mayor and over 1,000 citizens. Yet the Prime Minister and the industry minister could not be there: they sent a backbench member of the government, the member for La Trobe-who, as I said, was treated with every courtesy by those people whose future is threatened. That is the sort of thing that we are getting from this government. That is the sort of thing that the Australian nation is getting from this government. The Australian people are becoming increasingly aware of just what that decision in March of last year meant. I said when I started that Newcastle illustrates it well. Newcastle does illustrate it well, and Newcastle's reaction will illustrate the reaction of the Australian people. honourable member for Charlton( Mr Robert Brown) underlines the regional importance of proper industry policy. Those who have studied the Newcastle region know that what is really required is to put in place industry policies that take into account the effect on that region. Likewise, although the electorate that I represent is part of metropolitan Melbourne, in the northern suburbs of Melbourne there are two areas where there has been real need and real concern about the direction of this government with regard to industry policy. The areas are, of course, the automotive industry-the passenger vehicle assembly sector-and the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. If we take the total number of jobs in the northern and westem suburbs of Melbourne that are in those two industries, the decisions that are made by government have a great effect in a regional sense. And whilst sometimes that is clouded when you talk about regions within a metropolis like Melbourne, it is still very important.
