theText: The contribution that we have just heard from the5510 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 One of the disappointing aspects of the past 15 months or so of the government is the confusion that we see within this government on industry policy. If we look at the debate that we had over bounties-the backflips that we saw in the shipbuilding bounty, the backflips we saw on the robotic bounty and the backflips on the book bounty-it is of real concern that businesses in those sectors cannot really sit down and plan right through. Last week I had a meeting, in conjunction with the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), with some of the people who are involved in the automotive components industries in our two electorates. We had the honourable member for Hotham( Mr Crean), as the shadow minister, talk to them. One of the things that came out was the relief that they saw now that there had been a decision made in respect of the automotive industries. There was relief that they were able to now sit down and plan for the future. The government has to take into account the psychological effect that the lack of leadership-as the honourable member for Charlton( Mr Robert Brown) has highlighted-has had on industry policy. There is a need for government, and not only Minister Moore, to really look at industries. For instance, earlier in the year we had decisions made about the pharmaceutical industry, decisions that had to be put in place so that there could be a continuation and certainty in policy decisions by those in the pharmaceutical industry post the factor F scheme. Whilst there has been put in place some recognition of the importance the pharmaceutical industry has to Australia and there are to be forms of assistance, what this government has lost the plot on is matching industry policy against the effect that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme has on pharmaceutical companies within Australia. At the same time, successive governments, not only the Labor government before this one but the coalition governments before that, put the lid on the price of pharmaceuticals to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This, of course, has had an effect on the pharmaceutical industry. That has been acknowledged by all. That was the reason why the elements of the factor F were put in place, so that we could achieve two aims. They were to manage the level of expenditure under the PBS, but also keep a domestic pharmaceutical industry that could be then used for exports. We have had great success in that. That is always what in those dual senses we have to achieve with our policies. The honourable member for Wills( Mr Kelvin Thomson) has gone to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Finding a balance. The discussion of this is of crucial importance to the small business sector which is such a large employer within Australia. At the end of the day what we need to see in industry policy is the emphasis on the employment outcomes. The emphasis on the employment outcomes is our ability to manufacture here in Australia and to open up export markets so that we can ensure sustainable jobs, especially in the manufacturing industry. If this government is to achieve its aim to have 200,000 new jobs in the manufacturing industry by the year 2000, it has to keep that in mind. It has to protect manufacturing industry's ability to be able to make decisions that will ensure that we continue to achieve export markets. theText: Minister for Science and Technology) (10.09 p.m)-I thankTuesday, 17 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5511 matters surrounding industry policy raised by the member for Scullin also has had much airing in the main chamber. Turning now to the very interesting and important matter raised by the member for Wide Bay: it is not an unfamiliar issue with me given that he has made strong representations on behalf of Narayen Research Station for a long while now, and in that he is joined by the member for Hinkler( Mr Neville). It was very fair of the member for Wide Bay to mention the changing nature of research, to the point now where there is a question mark by the beef industry itself whether or not it wants to continue-and especially to the same financial tune-the research conducted at Narayen that previously went on. I expect to visit Narayen some time in the future but am unable to make a commitment at this time. 5512 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 17 June 1997 The member for Wills who is no longer with us raised the hoary old chestnut of the Franchising Code Council. May I remind the member for Wills, in his absence, that the Franchising Code Council chose to close down itself. Also, in fact, the government increased the funding available to the Franchising Code Council. briefly. draw my remarks to a conclusion, again thanking all the members for the vigorous manner in which they expressed their strongly held views. response that was made by the minister and also to assure the minister that I have not found the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism an insensitive person. I did not hear him say that; I did not see it in print. That is widely believed in the Newcastle region that the minister made that response. I hope that if he did not make that response that he will deny it. I will await that denial. The $1 billion that the value of BHP shares increased by within hours of that announcement having been made came out of the pockets, out of the food cupboards and off the dinner tables of those 2,500 to 7,000 individuals and families who will lose their jobs in Newcastle as a result of that decision. That is where that increase comes from. It is a direct transfer out of their pockets and out of their budgets straight into the pockets of those people who have shares in BHP. John Prescott earns $2.23 million every year; he is the boss of BHP. As a result of that decision, his shares went up, within hours, by $1.42 million in value. That is not bad to pick up. Ron McNeily, another top executive in BHP, as a result of that decision, within hours his share value went up by $639,000. Brian Loton did not do too well-his only went up by $146,000. Gerry Ellis's share value went up by almost three-quarters of a million dollars within hours of the decision being made that increased the value of BHP shares by $1 billion. I repeat: the decision by BHP was that in September 1999 primary steel production -in Newcastle will cease, with a direct loss of 2,500 jobs, an indirect loss of another 1,500 on-site contract jobs, and another 3,000 to 4,000 jobs in the Newcastle area. I do not suggest for a moment that they made their decision for the purpose of achieving that personal windfall; I do not believe they did. But they achieved the windfall as a result of a decision that they made which was prejudicial in the extreme, not only to Newcastle but to Australian industry, to Australia's future capacity in steel making, and to its position as a major and potentially greater steel exporting nation. Proposed expenditure agreed to. Debate (on motion by Mr Sercombe) adjourned. to make one comment. On behalf of all members of the HouseI make the point that we are pleased that throughout this debate the relevant ministers have been here for the whole of the debate for each section. I am reliably informed that this is the first time this has happened in some decades. Honourable members-Hear, hear! Main Committee adjourned at 10.19 p.m.
